mn139:3.1: This is adapted from the first sermon; text has _kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya_ which is a briefer expression that the original _kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogo_ at [sn56.11:2.3]().
mn139:3.9: “Local terms” is _janapadanirutti_. | _Samaññā_ (“label”, Sanskrit _samājñā_) ought not be confused with _sāmañña_ (“agreement”, “equality”, Sanskrit _sāmānya_).
mn139:12.4: This is not about “translating” the Dhamma wholesale, but about using local terms, as in the U.S. they say “soda” or “pop” in different regions. Compare [pli-tv-kd15:33.1.5](), which is about giving personalized glosses to terms (_sakāya niruttiya_). | _Pātī_ (“pot”) is from the root _√pā_, “to drink”. | _Patta_ (“bowl”), the masculine form of the same root, is the standard word for a mendicant’s alms bowl. | _Vittha_ (“plate”, variants _vitta_, _piṭṭha_) is unknown see _vitthaka_, a small bowl for sewing gear ([pli-tv-kd15:11.5.15]()). | _Sarāva_ (“dish”) is a shallow clay dish (Sanskrit _śarāva_, eg. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.1.4.12; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.8.1; Manu 6.56; also in Jain texts). | _Dhāropa_ (“vessel”, variant _harosa_) may be a dialectical variant of Sanskrit _dhāraka_, “vessel, receptacle”. | _Poṇa_ (“tureen”) is probably a “sloped” dish. | _Pisīla_ (“porringer”) is a wooden bowl (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.5.3.6: _piśīle vā pātryau vā_).
mn139:14.3: This was apparently prompted by Subhūti’s support of his fellow monk Saddha at [an11.14 ](), for which he was declared the foremost in living without conflict ([an1.201:1.1](); he was additionally praised as worthy of donations ([an1.202:1.1](). Subhūti’s meditation is praised at [ud6.7](), and his verse opens the Theragāthā at [thag1.1]().
